metadata.title: Brazil Inequality Dataset
metadata.description: Comprehensive data on poverty, labor, and wealth inequality in Brazil, compiled from official sources including IBGE, World Bank, and Forbes.
metadata.data_currency: Data reflects 2023-2024 statistics with noted exceptions

ibge_pnad_2023.name: Pesquisa Nacional por Amostra de Domicílios Contínua 2023
ibge_pnad_2023.publisher: IBGE - Instituto Brasileiro de Geografia e Estatística
ibge_pnad_2023.notes: Official household survey covering employment, income, and living conditions

world_bank_poverty_2024.name: World Bank Poverty & Inequality Platform
world_bank_poverty_2024.notes: International poverty lines using 2017 PPP conversion rates

ipea_social_2023.name: Políticas Sociais: Acompanhamento e Análise
ipea_social_2023.publisher: IPEA - Instituto de Pesquisa Econômica Aplicada
ipea_social_2023.notes: Analysis of social program impacts on poverty reduction

credit_suisse_wealth_2023.name: Global Wealth Report 2023
credit_suisse_wealth_2023.notes: Wealth distribution and millionaire population estimates

forbes_billionaires_2024.name: Forbes World's Billionaires List 2024
forbes_billionaires_2024.notes: Annual count of individuals with net worth exceeding $1 billion

oxfam_inequality_2024.name: Inequality Inc. Report
oxfam_inequality_2024.notes: Analysis of wealth concentration and inequality trends

poverty.measurement_basis: Poverty rates calculated using World Bank international poverty lines (2017 PPP), with extreme poverty defined as living on less than $2.15/day and poverty as less than $6.85/day.

wealth.measurement_notes: Wealth estimates based on Credit Suisse Global Wealth Report methodology. Millionaire threshold uses USD at market exchange rates. Wealth distribution data has higher uncertainty than income data due to reliance on surveys and estimates of unreported assets.

billionaire_population.notes: Billionaire count increased by 11.3% year-over-year. Combined wealth of Brazilian billionaires estimated at $179.4 billion in 2025.

removed_fields.reason_removed: Removed to focus on distributional metrics rather than averages that obscure inequality
Composite indices removed in favor of specific, actionable poverty metrics
Definition varies significantly across sources; replaced with poverty line metrics for clarity

removed_or_deprecated.rationale: This dataset prioritizes metrics that directly measure inequality and poverty rather than aggregate indicators that can mask distributional concerns. Removed fields may be available in source datasets for users requiring them.

known_limitations: Wealth data relies heavily on survey responses and may undercount hidden assets
Regional poverty figures may not capture intra-regional urban/rural disparities
Racial categories follow Brazilian census classifications which differ from other countries
Informal sector income is difficult to measure accurately
PPP conversion rates introduce some uncertainty in international comparisons
